name: hc_stressor_cascade_boss
description: [HC] Hospital rooftop kitchen marine + GDC-FLEX RF 600x600 3000‚ÜíMULTI-BLOCK
query: Rooftop kitchen exhaust for a hospital. Marine climate. 3000 m¬≥/h. We want GDC-FLEX RF 600x600.

turns.content: Rooftop kitchen exhaust for a hospital. Marine climate. 3000 m¬≥/h. We want GDC-FLEX RF 600x600.

For the rooftop kitchen exhaust at the hospital, the GDC_FLEX filter you requested is not suitable for marine environments. The single-wall uninsulated construction does not meet leakage and hygiene requirements, and the C2 housing is not rated for salt spray, which accelerates corrosion. To ensure proper filtration and longevity, I recommend a multi-stage filtration system.This system will address several environmental stressors present in your application, including High Humidity, Chemical Vapor Exposure, Outdoor Condensation, Grease/Oil Exposure, Salt Spray, and Hygiene Requirements. Grease/Oil Exposure is particularly critical, as lipids can permanently deactivate carbon filters. The solution involves a mechanical pre-filter (GDP Planfiltersk√•p) to capture grease and particulate, followed by a carbon filter (GDMI Modulfiltersk√•p) for odor and gas removal.The system will consist of two stages, both using 600x600mm modules to handle the 3000 m¬≥/h airflow. Since the required airflow exceeds the capacity of a single 600x600 module, we'll need two modules in parallel, resulting in effective housing dimensions of 1200x600mm. To finalize the configuration, I need the filter depth for the GDMI Modulfiltersk√•p.What is the filter depth for the GDMI Modulfiltersk√•p?

gemini.explanation: The system correctly identifies that the requested GDC-FLEX housing is unsuitable for a marine rooftop application due to its single-wall uninsulated construction and standard C2 corrosion rating. It proposes a technically sound multi-stage solution (Grease Pre-filter + Carbon) using the insulated GDMI housing, which is available in C5-rated Magnelis (ZM). The sizing logic correctly derates the airflow for carbon filtration, prioritizing residence time over the raw hydraulic capacity listed in the PDF.

dimension_explanations.correctness: Correctly identifies GDC-FLEX as indoor/C2 (PDF p.16) and GDMI as insulated/C5-capable (PDF p.11); correctly applies engineering judgment to derate airflow for carbon filtration.
dimension_explanations.completeness: Addresses environment, hygiene, and grease risks comprehensively; slightly implicit regarding the material switch from the requested RF (Stainless) to ZM (Magnelis) for the GDMI housing.
dimension_explanations.safety: Excellent identification of critical risks: grease fouling carbon, marine corrosion, and condensation in uninsulated housings.
dimension_explanations.reasoning_quality: Clear logical progression from environmental constraints -> product rejection -> multi-stage solution proposal -> sizing calculation.
dimension_explanations.constraint_adherence: Strictly adheres to the 'Indoor use' and 'C2' constraints of the requested product, blocking it despite the user's request.

strengths: Correctly prioritizes engineering constraints (Marine/Condensation) over user product request
Applies advanced HVAC knowledge (Grease deactivating carbon) not explicitly in the PDF
Sound sizing logic for carbon filtration (splitting 3000 m¬≥/h into two modules)
weaknesses: Could explicitly clarify that GDMI is not available in RF (Stainless) per PDF p.11, but that ZM satisfies the Marine requirement
Did not explicitly specify that the pre-filter (GDP) must also be ordered in a marine-grade material/insulated enclosure
pdf_citations: GDC FLEX: 'F√∂r inomhusbruk', 'Korrosivitets klass C2', 'oisolerat' (PDF p.16)
GDMI: 'v√§rme- och kondensisolerat', 'Korrosivitets klass C5' (ZM) (PDF p.11)

openai.explanation: The response correctly flags key risks (marine rooftop exposure, grease deactivating carbon) and appropriately blocks the requested GDC FLEX for this application. However, it makes several catalog-inconsistent claims (material/corrosion class and construction) and proposes an incorrect sizing approach (two 600x600 in parallel for 3000 m¬≥/h) while asking for an irrelevant parameter (filter depth) for GDMI.

dimension_explanations.correctness: PDF shows GDC FLEX 600x600 has rek. fl√∂de 1750 m¬≥/h (so two modules would be 3500 m¬≥/h) and GDMI 600x600 has fl√∂de 3400 m¬≥/h, but the system incorrectly states GDC FLEX is ‚ÄúC2‚Äù and ‚Äúsingle-wall uninsulated‚Äù and that 3000 m¬≥/h exceeds a 600x600 module; the grease/carbon warning is sound engineering practice.
dimension_explanations.completeness: It does not converge to a viable rooftop/marine/hospital-kitchen solution (e.g., weatherproof/insulated/hygienic execution, drainage/condensation strategy, and correct stage selection) and stops at an unnecessary question.
dimension_explanations.safety: Good risk identification: marine corrosion, outdoor condensation, and grease fouling of carbon are correctly highlighted, and blocking the proposed carbon stage without proper pre-treatment is prudent.
dimension_explanations.tone: Professional, clear, and appropriately consultative for a technical sales/engineering context.
dimension_explanations.reasoning_quality: Reasoning is generally structured (environment ‚Üí risks ‚Üí staged filtration), but contains logical jumps and contradictions versus the catalog (capacity and construction claims).
dimension_explanations.constraint_adherence: Violates catalog constraints by mischaracterizing available material/corrosion class and by selecting two 600x600 modules in parallel when one GDMI 600x600 already covers 3000 m¬≥/h per the PDF.

strengths: Correctly blocks an unsafe/unsuitable configuration for a marine rooftop kitchen exhaust and highlights grease deactivation of carbon media.
Uses a staged-filtration concept and calls out multiple relevant environmental stressors (humidity/condensation/salt spray/hygiene).
weaknesses: Multiple catalog mismatches: claims GDC FLEX is C2 and single-wall uninsulated, and claims 3000 m¬≥/h exceeds a 600x600 module (it does not for GDMI, and two GDC FLEX would exceed it).

Asks for ‚Äúfilter depth for GDMI‚Äù even though GDMI is a bag/compact filter housing (length selection is relevant, not ‚Äòfilter depth‚Äô), and it doesn‚Äôt address rooftop weatherproofing/hygienic execution details needed for a hospital kitchen exhaust.
pdf_citations: GDC FLEX 600x600: Rek. fl√∂de 1750 m¬≥/h; lengths 750/800 or 900/950 (catalog section 'GDC FLEX', table 'M√ÖTT').
GDMI 600x600: Fl√∂de 3400 m¬≥/h; lengths 600/650 or 850/900 (catalog section 'GDMI', table 'M√ÖTT').

content_segments.text: For the rooftop kitchen exhaust at the hospital, the GDC_FLEX filter you requested is not suitable for marine environments. The single-wall uninsulated construction does not meet leakage and hygiene requirements, and the C2 housing is not rated for salt spray, which accelerates corrosion. To ensure proper filtration and longevity, I recommend a multi-stage filtration system.

This system will address several environmental stressors present in your application, including High Humidity, Chemical Vapor Exposure, Outdoor Condensation, Grease/Oil Exposure, Salt Spray, and Hygiene Requirements. Grease/Oil Exposure is particularly critical, as lipids can permanently deactivate carbon filters. The solution involves a mechanical pre-filter (GDP Planfiltersk√•p) to capture grease and particulate, followed by a carbon filter (GDMI Modulfiltersk√•p) for odor and gas removal.

The system will consist of two stages, both using 600x600mm modules to handle the 3000 m¬≥/h airflow. Since the required airflow exceeds the capacity of a single 600x600 module, we'll need two modules in parallel, resulting in effective housing dimensions of 1200x600mm. To finalize the configuration, I need the filter depth for the GDMI Modulfiltersk√•p.
What is the filter depth for the GDMI Modulfiltersk√•p?
